David Saff wrote:

> J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>  > A stateless abstract class is usually a Strategy, so I'd rather use it
>  > than extend it.
> 
> Meaning you'd rather declare it as an interface?

Absolutely. As a concrete class, I'd rather use a Strategy (compose it 
as a separate type), than extend it (as a subclass). The separate type 
would almost certainly be an interface.

>  > One exception is the empty Strategy, otherwise known as
>  > an Adapter.
> 
> That's a different definition of Adapter than I'm used to (or a
> different application).

I might not be using the GoF's meaning of Adapter strictly here. When I 
hear "Adapter" I think of a no-op implementation of a set of abstract 
methods that I can extend so that if I want empty implementations of 9 
out of 10 methods, I only need to override one.

> I think I'm about to learn something...

Anything's possible. (I couldn't resist that one.)
